But there are other subjects taught at the university, in which no such advantages are
offered, in which the undergraduate is placed entirely under the care of men whose reputations
are yet to be won. We know well that the object of the university authorities is to offer us
the best advantages in their power; we know that, if we accept President Hadley's ideas as to
what a college system should be, we have a curriculum as wisely laid out as that of any other
college in this country; yet in the one particular mentioned above, we feel that a reform could
well be instituted.
The reputation of a university can not rest entirely on her graduate department.
If she is to exist and prosper for all time, she must turn her kindest thoughts to those
from whom come the life of the university. To the younger man should she give the greatest
opportunities, rather than to the older hero whose wagon is already hitched—nay, firmly
clamped—to the star of the Ph.D., dimly twinkling in the distance.

T would be unjust, if not criminal, if the NEWS—LETTER were not to
make conspicuous mention of a new phase of university life recently
. ,z.,z
come to light. In the "Magistrate," as given by the Hare's Foot
Club, we find not only a display of amateur talent which the underit
graduates may feel proud to have produced, but also a better and
healthier quality for the university as a whole. The one thing which
keeps a university alive, which makes it ten times dearer and more
valuable, to her students is her so-called college spirit.
•
We do not only admire and applaud for its own sake, the
spirit shown by the members of the Hare's Foot Club, but we
welcome it as definitely stamping a new era in college spirit at this university. When we
applaud the acting or general success of particular men connected with the play, we do not
wish to appear unduly impressed by the prowess of any individual. What we want to say,
what we rejoice that we can say, is that every man did his best. Let us all see to it that the
spirit shown in many hours of tedious recitals is 'fully" appreciated, that for the sake of the
university we join one and all in praise of the members of "The Magistrate.."

THE NEWS-LETTER.

BALDY'S LITTLE JOKE.
He had sneaked into Talca like a lost dog
who wanted to get a winter's grub, but who
did not want to be put back in a sled team.
No blaring bands or 'Welcome to Our City"
banners greeted him. No one knew him. No
one knew what he was. He quietly slipped
into a room at the Golden Dream, our best
hostelry because.there was no other. All day
he "messed" about the diggings, and all night
he hung around the edges of the crowd in
the Dream's bar. Who he was nobody cared,
but what he was caused much speculation.
His extremities—his new cow-hide boots, his
jaunty Stetson, his white hands—seemed to
indicate a college-made miner, but it was evident that he knew even less about mines than
a 'consulting engineer." He might have
been a speculator, but he wore a flannel shirt.
The angle at which he carried his gun precluded the idea that he was a puncher turned
prospector. He did not talk like an Englishman nor look like an Easterner. He did not
stake a claim. He bought no dust. He did
not gamble. He opened no store nor saloon.
It was finally decided—and public opinion
was pretty evenly divided—that he was either
a consumptive up for his health or a detective
up for the government, and as all Talca either
had colds or records he was not overburdened
with friends.
It was discovered, however, in one of those
mysterious ways in which news gets about in
a mining country, that he was the author of
an Alaskan story, and was, in all probability,
in Talca looking for material and local color
for another similar novel. At least that was
Jim Goodwin's theory, and Jim, having been
to college somewhere in the East, was considered an oracle on matters pertaining to aft
and literature.
“Let's give him some material," suggested
Leggie" Warner one evening in the Dream's
bar-room, "some of the real stuff, red hot off
the griddle like Dirty Bill's flap-jacks."
Accordingly every evening when the crowd
had collected one after another became reminiscent and told story after story. What
stories those were! There were tales of the
luckiest of big ore strikes, of the wildest of
blizzards, of the most marvelous dog teams,
of the biggest poker and monte games. There
'

were hunting stories, prospecting stories,
hold-up stories, wild animal stories, Indian
stories, even love-stories, and each was more
impossible than its predecessor. The tenderfoot drank them all ill and you could see him
jotting them down in his mental note-book
for future reference. The imaginations of the
Talcaeans were vivid, but exhaustable, and
the stories at last began to deteriorate.
Just when the yarns became so poor that
even the tenderfoot's suspicion was aroused,
Baldy Kirk thought of his little joke. Somewhere he chanced upon a copy of that great
Alaskan novel and as he said afterwards, he
'nearly broke his belt laughing." Of all the
red iculous descriptions and situations the most
rediculous in the book was the fight between
the hero and a bad man. The absurdity of
this gave Baldy, who is a great practical joker,
an idea. First he got Jack Carter, who was
working a claim down on Crooked Creek, to
masquerade as a bad man. Jack was the man
for the part. lie is big, raw-boned, broad
shouldered, black haired, and on occasion can
look most savage, though in real life he is a
mild, quiet fellow. He is moreover a sure
shot and could be trusted to shoot; scare and
yet do no harm.
Two days before Carter was to come to
Talca and play desperado, we were all in the
Dream listening to Duncan McNab telling
about his dogs playing leap-frog with a pack
of wolves. When Scotty had finished, Baldy
said, "I was over to'Tingley today and they
told me that they heard from the Fort that
Jack Carter had come out of the upper Yukon
country and is up to his old game."
'Not Roaring Jack Carter?'
"Sure. He's killed a mail carrier on the
Dawson trail an's heading this way."
This news caused a great sensation, and
stories beyond number were told of ``the worst
man north of Seattle." The next evening the
sheriff, who was in the plot, announced that
Roaring Jack had had five thousand dollars
posted on his head by both the Canadian
Northwestern Mounted Polic and Uncle Sam.
More stories were told till the histories of
Jessie James, Tracey and Billy the Kid combined would look like the adventures of some
New England village cut-up beside Carter's
crimes. All agreed that there were easier

ways of making $10,000, and reckoned Carter
would not find any obstacle in them.

the little joke. It cured Baldy of being a

. "THE MAGISTRATE."
In another part of this issue, we have
expressed something of the praise due to the
members of the Hare's Foot Club. It is too
late to declare that the play was a success,
if this article is to be looked on in the light of
a news-item, so we take the liberty of criticising the different members of the cast.
Mr. C. H. Goddard, '11, proved most entertaining in the role of Mr. Posket. At
times Mr. Goddard was indeed brilliant and
his acting excited admiration on all sides. We

Mr. Weems, '09, as Mrs. Posket, had a
most difficult part to play and carried it
through with great success. Mr. Weems
acted in a way that showed he was thoroughly
in the spirit of the occasion. He was one of
the most successful of the players. In the
fainting scene at the end of the second act,
•Mr. Weems introduced an unexpected novelty
which literally brought down the house. (We
speak here from the point of view of the first
night). Seriously speaking, we wish most
sincerely to congratulate Mr. Weems on a
most excellent rendering of a difficult part.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

We would fain conjure up additional adjectives for the young ladies of the affair, namely,
Mr. F. C. Lee, '12, as Charlotte Verrinder,
and Mr. H. Haupt, '12, as Bertie Tomlinson,
but with our limited vocabulary we may only
say that the ladies were charming, beautiful,
attractive, with fair complexions and a winning grace. Mr. Lee was very entertaining
and was one of the most successful actors.
Mr. Haupt was also very good in his acting,
pnrticularly with Cis Farringdon.
Of the other characters of the play we can
only speak praise. Mr. Hayne, '11, as the
proprietor of the Hotel des Princes, was
thoroughly disguised and familiar with his
part. Mr. Buckler, '12, as chief clerk had
not a difficult part, but performed it well.
Mr. Bosley, as Inspector Messiter was excellent and was well supported by J. S. Fulton,
'12, and R. S. McCabe, '11, as constables.
Mr. Waters, '11, as Isadore, a waiter, was so
entertaining that we wish he had appeared
oftener. Mr. Janney Smith, '09, as the maid
at Posket's, was well disguised and as well
"up" in his part as the rest.
The musical program, conducted by Mr.
Edwin Litchfield Turnbull, Johns Hopkins,
'83, proved excellent. Mr. Turnbull took no
little trouble to make this successful.
•
The program was gotten out with considerable care and the business manager, Mr. J.
G. Murray, showed considerable ability in
handling this important part of the production.
One man who has not yet been mentioned,
yet who deserves our heartiest thanks is Dr.
Ogden, of the University, who devoted a
great part of his time to making the "Magistrate" a success. We wish to thank him on
behalf of the students at the University.
It is needless to say again that the "Magistrate" was worth while. May the play next
year be as successful !

THE HARE'S FOOT CLUB.
We are alway's glad to recognize a new
example of college spirit. The men who
went into the "Magistrate" with the persistency and earnestness necessary to make the
play a success, deserve our thanks and best
wishes. This is a true example of what college spirit can accomplish. May this spirit
grow ever stronger, never weaker!

BASEBALL TEAM.
Last year we just missed having an official
baseball team. We have seen this year's
Hopkins spirit among us shown by the efforts
of the members of the Hare's Foot Club. A
baseball team can'be accomplished this year if
there is enough energy to start the thing going
and keep it moving. In our opinion, this
scheme is possible. While there is time, let
the seniors at the university start a crusade.
If the seniors will not, how about other men
in the university? We wish to see some energy
lint into play here!

TENNIS-COURTS AT HOMEWOOD.
There have long been rumors of tenniscourts at Homewood. The Athletic Association is to be held to account for the existence
or non-existence of tennis-courts THIS SPRING.
There is plenty of room at Homewood. Not
all men who pay dues to the Athletic Association play lacrosse or football. Why not give
the silent member a chance!

NEXT YEAR'S"HULLABALOO."
Owing to the change from the three to the
four-year system, the senior class will be very
small next year. It will he too small to publish the Hullabaloo;and the members of''1910"
will appear in the 1909 Hullabaloo. The
)will be called
juniors next year (i. e., "1911,"
on to publish the year-book. As this is, we
believe, the custom in many colleges, next
year is a good opportunity to start a new
iarrangement. This year's sophomore class
has not elected a Hullabaloo Board for next
year. This should be done at once!

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE DEBATE.
The debating season has again rolled 'round.
That we should always be the victors is not
true to life; that we should present a
thoroughly equipped and bristling front to
the enemy is necessary. The debaters need
men to help them in their research work.
Report either to Dr. French, Mr. Marvel, or
Mr. Russell. On the night of the debate, do
not only be present; as the poet (Latin 2.)
has it: '`Favele linguis!"—keep holy silence!

Ben Weems and Freddy Lee would have
made ideal girls if they had been playing in
Chicago.
Alan Woods showed that he was a practical
when he kissed Charlotte. Freddy didn't
like it a bit.
Did you ever see Dr. Ogden at a loss for a
word before?
Sergeant Lugg (Jack Fulton) deserves a
beat in Highlandtown.
Dick McCabe, if he tried hard enough,
might make the beauty squad.

THE DANCE.
We do not think that scientific descriptions
of the sun's rays and similar ornaments are
suitable decorations for McCoy Hall on the
night of the dance. We think that the Dance
Committee should be careful in the future to
have them removed and more modern pictures
substituted. We also make the stock suggestion that more chaperons be persuaded to
come. Both of these things could easily be
arranged if the Dance Committee would be
willing to take a little extra trouble.

Billy Haynes looked as young as those in
the graduating class at the Calvert School.
It is difficult to do justice to Teddy Guerad
and Calvin Goddard.
''Ham' Owens improved with time.
was delicious on the second night.

He

Chauncy Bosley threatens to become a
Pinkerton detective.
Berry Waters could hardly keep from waiting on the table at the Sophomore Banquet.
Harvey Hayne for fear of the police came in
late.
"Babe" Michael had more gold on his
uniform than he had in his pocket.

COMPETITION IN COLLEGE.
III view of President Hadley's remarkably
able address delivered a few days ago at the
university, may we venture to make a suggestion? Dr. Hadley calls for the element of
competition to appear in the undergraduate
colleges. Surely Princeton has well answered
this question by establishing 'honor groups."
The classes here are not very large, but in
cases where the number is over thirty, ought
not `'honor groups" to be established? Surely
this is a certain way of obtaining competition.

FROM BEFORE THE FOOTLIGHTS.
Leslie Buckler, as Mr. Warrington, wore a
hat.

Harold Haupt looked very uncomfortable.
Janney Smith had a superb figure.

Sonnet; Voiture and Austin Dobson have
written Rondeau on the Rondeau; Swinburne
a rondel on the Rondel. How about this
triolet on the Triolet?—S. C. C.]
The Triolet's done

E'er you're sure it's begun
The Triolet's done;
But writing them's fun
And really worth trying—
The Triolet's done
As a moment is flying.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

TRACK NOTES.
Saturday, February 13th, was a day of disappointment for our track team, for adverse
circumstances caused the downfall of both of
our relay teams. Our mile-relay team competed for the indoor collegiate championship
in the Columbia Games, New York, and,
owing to the spill of the ffrst man, Bridgman,
lost their chances to make good. It is said
that the track was in wretched condition at
the curves and this was the reason of 'Bridgman's fall. It is doubtful, however, whether
we could have beaten Harvard, for the time,
3.32 4-5 is better than a Black and Blue university team has ever done. The men ran in
the following order: Bridgeman, Baily (captain), Fulton, Stollenwerck.
Our two mile relay team were entered in
the George Washington Games, in Washington. When they arrived at the Convention
Hall, they were informed that there was no
two mile team to compete with them; so they
were forced to run the crack Cornell mile
relay. One concession was made, however,
and that is that the distance was set at a mile
and a quarter. Of course the Cornell men
ran away from our distance men, so there is
no more to say about it. The team was composed of Breyer, Makel, Burgas' and Griffith.
In the mile handicap event "Dutch" Breyer
made good. He started from scratch, and
overtaking a field of 31, finished third.

INVITATION FROM PENN.
Manager Stewart, of the Track Team, has
received an invitation to name entries for the
15th annual relay races to be held by the
University of Pennsylvania on Saturday,
April 25th.
The invitation, in part, reads as follows:
"There will be three races to determine the
college championship of America, and they
will be open to any college or university that
desires to enter. One race will be for a distance of a mile, each man to run a quartermile. The second race will be a four mile
race, each mass to run a mile. The third race
will be a two mile race, each man to run a
half mile. The University of Pennsylvania
will be found in all three, and it is expected

that Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Cornell,
Columbia, Chicago, Michigan, Wisconsin,
etc., will also enter them."
'There will be in addition a number of other
races between colleges."
"The relay races have now become so well
known that we hope you will snake a special
effort to send A team. Each year all the big
colleges and schools with hardly an exception
are on hand. The championships and special
events are very high class while the group
races are most interesting. Over 200 teams
have been present for several years, making
this the biggest meet of the year. To be
absent from the relay races is to miss an
athletic treat."
"We shall award the following prizes: A
silk banner will be given to the winning team
as a college trophy, and to each member of
the winning team a gold watch. To each of
the members of the team that finishes second
we shall give a silver cup. Cups will be
given as third prizes. If only three colleges
are able to enter the race, we shall give a silk
banner to the winning team, and a gold watch
to each of its members. Second prizes will be
given when four teams contest, third prizes
will be given when six teams contest. In
case your institution should enter and the
other colleges with which we have classed
you should not enter, we shall make arrangements to put you in a race with some other
teams about your equal in strength."
"We expect to give the following scratch
events, open only to college men, graduate or
undergraduate, in which the first prize will be
a gold watch: One hundred yards dash, 120yards hurdle, high jump, broad jump, shot
put, hammer throw, discus and pole vault."
``The races will be governed by the same
rules of qualification that now prevail in the
Intercollegiate Athletic Association."
``No entrance fee will be charged."

THE SOPHOMORE BANQUET.
The Sophomore Banquet was held at the
New St. James Hotel, on Friday, February
18th. It was most successful in every way.
The toastmaster was Harvey Musser, who
was very happy in his remarks. The following toasts were responded to: Harry C. Burgan, president, to our class; W. B. Waters, to
the football team; E. 0. Hulbert, to the
lacrosse team; Ben. Tappan, to the track
team; and Mason Patillo, to "those that have
fallen by the wayside."
The speeches were fine and to the point and
the singing, led by the famous Wilson and
A general
Cooper quartet was excellent.
atmosphere of good nature and "roughhouse" prevailed, and after a rousing cheer
for the class of nineteen eleven the banquet
broke up—no one feeling the worse for the

The street car was crowded. The perspiring conductor pushed his way to the platform,
rang up a dozen or so fares, and then gave a
sigh of relief. The worst part of his work
was done.
The car went on to the next transfer station
and then stopped. A fashionably dressed
woman made her way to the door, and,
pausing before she lighted, opened up her
pocketbook, took out a dollar bill, handed it

Chocolates

Bonbons

to the conductor, and sweetly said:
"You forgot to collect my fare, my good
man."
The conductor gave her ninety-five cents
change, touched his hat, and. turning to a
passenger, said:
"Now, that's what I call a perfect lady."
But suddenly the smile froze on his lips,
for, as he looked more closely at the dollar
bill, he saw that it was counterfeit.

are yet to be won. We know well that the object of the university authorities is to offer us
the best advantages in their power; we know that, if we accept President Hadley's ideas as to
what a college system should be, we have a curriculum as wisely laid out as that of any other
college in this country; yet in the one particular mentioned above, we feel that a reform could
well be instituted.
The reputation of a university can not rest entirely on her graduate department.
If she is to exist and prosper for all time, she must turn her kindest thoughts to those
from whom come the life of the university. To the younger man should she give the greatest
opportunities, rather than to the older hero whose wagon is already hitched—nay, firmly
clamped—to the star of the Ph.D., dimly twinkling in the distance.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

BALDY'S LITTLE JOKE.
He had sneaked into Talca like a lost dog
who wanted to get a winter's grub, but who
did not want to be put back in a sled team.
No blaring bands or 'Welcome to Our City"
banners greeted him. No one knew him. No
one knew what he was. He quietly slipped
into a room at the Golden Dream, our best
hostelry because.there was no other. All day
he "messed" about the diggings, and all night
he hung around the edges of the crowd in
the Dream's bar. Who he was nobody cared,
but what he was caused much speculation.
His extremities—his new cow-hide boots, his
jaunty Stetson, his white hands—seemed to
indicate a college-made miner, but it was evident that he knew even less about mines than
a 'consulting engineer." He might have
been a speculator, but he wore a flannel shirt.
The angle at which he carried his gun precluded the idea that he was a puncher turned
prospector. He did not talk like an Englishman nor look like an Easterner. He did not
stake a claim. He bought no dust. He did
not gamble. He opened no store nor saloon.
It was finally decided—and public opinion
was pretty evenly divided—that he was either
a consumptive up for his health or a detective
up for the government, and as all Talca either
had colds or records he was not overburdened
with friends.
It was discovered, however, in one of those
mysterious ways in which news gets about in
a mining country, that he was the author of
an Alaskan story, and was, in all probability,
in Talca looking for material and local color
for another similar novel. At least that was
Jim Goodwin's theory, and Jim, having been
to college somewhere in the East, was considered an oracle on matters pertaining to aft
and literature.
“Let's give him some material," suggested
Leggie" Warner one evening in the Dream's
bar-room, "some of the real stuff, red hot off
the griddle like Dirty Bill's flap-jacks."
Accordingly every evening when the crowd
had collected one after another became reminiscent and told story after story. What
stories those were! There were tales of the
luckiest of big ore strikes, of the wildest of
blizzards, of the most marvelous dog teams,
of the biggest poker and monte games. There
'

were hunting stories, prospecting stories,
hold-up stories, wild animal stories, Indian
stories, even love-stories, and each was more
impossible than its predecessor. The tenderfoot drank them all ill and you could see him
jotting them down in his mental note-book
for future reference. The imaginations of the
Talcaeans were vivid, but exhaustable, and
the stories at last began to deteriorate.
Just when the yarns became so poor that
even the tenderfoot's suspicion was aroused,
Baldy Kirk thought of his little joke. Somewhere he chanced upon a copy of that great
Alaskan novel and as he said afterwards, he
'nearly broke his belt laughing." Of all the
red iculous descriptions and situations the most
rediculous in the book was the fight between
the hero and a bad man. The absurdity of
this gave Baldy, who is a great practical joker,
an idea. First he got Jack Carter, who was
working a claim down on Crooked Creek, to
masquerade as a bad man. Jack was the man
for the part. lie is big, raw-boned, broad
shouldered, black haired, and on occasion can
look most savage, though in real life he is a
mild, quiet fellow. He is moreover a sure
shot and could be trusted to shoot; scare and
yet do no harm.
Two days before Carter was to come to
Talca and play desperado, we were all in the
Dream listening to Duncan McNab telling
about his dogs playing leap-frog with a pack
of wolves. When Scotty had finished, Baldy
said, "I was over to'Tingley today and they
told me that they heard from the Fort that
Jack Carter had come out of the upper Yukon
country and is up to his old game."
'Not Roaring Jack Carter?'
"Sure. He's killed a mail carrier on the
Dawson trail an's heading this way."
This news caused a great sensation, and
stories beyond number were told of ``the worst
man north of Seattle." The next evening the
sheriff, who was in the plot, announced that
Roaring Jack had had five thousand dollars
posted on his head by both the Canadian
Northwestern Mounted Polic and Uncle Sam.
More stories were told till the histories of
Jessie James, Tracey and Billy the Kid combined would look like the adventures of some
New England village cut-up beside Carter's
crimes. All agreed that there were easier

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ways of making $10,000, and reckoned Carter
would not find any obstacle in them.

'`Forget it,' answered the reformed' desperado. ''He's got nerve and he meant business."
— Boys," said Baldy after a pause, '`Jack's
right and drinks is on me. Set 'em up, Harris. Boys, here's to the cussedest tenderfoot
ever hit the country!"
Anywhere within a radius of two hundred

hearty laugh at Baldy Kirk's expense by

the little joke. It cured Baldy of being a
practical joker and the tenderfoot of writing

. "THE MAGISTRATE."
In another part of this issue, we have
expressed something of the praise due to the
members of the Hare's Foot Club. It is too
late to declare that the play was a success,
if this article is to be looked on in the light of
a news-item, so we take the liberty of criticising the different members of the cast.
Mr. C. H. Goddard, '11, proved most entertaining in the role of Mr. Posket. At
times Mr. Goddard was indeed brilliant and
his acting excited admiration on all sides. We

Mr. Weems, '09, as Mrs. Posket, had a
most difficult part to play and carried it
through with great success. Mr. Weems
acted in a way that showed he was thoroughly
in the spirit of the occasion. He was one of
the most successful of the players. In the
fainting scene at the end of the second act,
•Mr. Weems introduced an unexpected novelty
which literally brought down the house. (We
speak here from the point of view of the first
night). Seriously speaking, we wish most
sincerely to congratulate Mr. Weems on a
most excellent rendering of a difficult part.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

We would fain conjure up additional adjectives for the young ladies of the affair, namely,
Mr. F. C. Lee, '12, as Charlotte Verrinder,
and Mr. H. Haupt, '12, as Bertie Tomlinson,
but with our limited vocabulary we may only
say that the ladies were charming, beautiful,
attractive, with fair complexions and a winning grace. Mr. Lee was very entertaining
and was one of the most successful actors.
Mr. Haupt was also very good in his acting,
pnrticularly with Cis Farringdon.
Of the other characters of the play we can
only speak praise. Mr. Hayne, '11, as the
proprietor of the Hotel des Princes, was
thoroughly disguised and familiar with his
part. Mr. Buckler, '12, as chief clerk had
not a difficult part, but performed it well.
Mr. Bosley, as Inspector Messiter was excellent and was well supported by J. S. Fulton,
'12, and R. S. McCabe, '11, as constables.
Mr. Waters, '11, as Isadore, a waiter, was so
entertaining that we wish he had appeared
oftener. Mr. Janney Smith, '09, as the maid
at Posket's, was well disguised and as well
"up" in his part as the rest.
The musical program, conducted by Mr.
Edwin Litchfield Turnbull, Johns Hopkins,
'83, proved excellent. Mr. Turnbull took no
little trouble to make this successful.
•
The program was gotten out with considerable care and the business manager, Mr. J.
G. Murray, showed considerable ability in
handling this important part of the production.
One man who has not yet been mentioned,
yet who deserves our heartiest thanks is Dr.
Ogden, of the University, who devoted a
great part of his time to making the "Magistrate" a success. We wish to thank him on
behalf of the students at the University.
It is needless to say again that the "Magistrate" was worth while. May the play next
year be as successful !

THE HARE'S FOOT CLUB.
We are alway's glad to recognize a new
example of college spirit. The men who
went into the "Magistrate" with the persistency and earnestness necessary to make the
play a success, deserve our thanks and best
wishes. This is a true example of what college spirit can accomplish. May this spirit
grow ever stronger, never weaker!

BASEBALL TEAM.
Last year we just missed having an official
baseball team. We have seen this year's
Hopkins spirit among us shown by the efforts
of the members of the Hare's Foot Club. A
baseball team can'be accomplished this year if
there is enough energy to start the thing going
and keep it moving. In our opinion, this
scheme is possible. While there is time, let
the seniors at the university start a crusade.
If the seniors will not, how about other men
in the university? We wish to see some energy
lint into play here!

TENNIS-COURTS AT HOMEWOOD.
There have long been rumors of tenniscourts at Homewood. The Athletic Association is to be held to account for the existence
or non-existence of tennis-courts THIS SPRING.
There is plenty of room at Homewood. Not
all men who pay dues to the Athletic Association play lacrosse or football. Why not give
the silent member a chance!

Owing to the change from the three to the
four-year system, the senior class will be very
small next year. It will he too small to publish the Hullabaloo;and the members of''1910"
will appear in the 1909 Hullabaloo. The
)will be called
juniors next year (i. e., "1911,"
on to publish the year-book. As this is, we
believe, the custom in many colleges, next
year is a good opportunity to start a new
iarrangement. This year's sophomore class
has not elected a Hullabaloo Board for next
year. This should be done at once!

THE DEBATE.
The debating season has again rolled 'round.
That we should always be the victors is not
true to life; that we should present a
thoroughly equipped and bristling front to
the enemy is necessary. The debaters need
men to help them in their research work.
Report either to Dr. French, Mr. Marvel, or
Mr. Russell. On the night of the debate, do
not only be present; as the poet (Latin 2.)
has it: '`Favele linguis!"—keep holy silence!

Ben Weems and Freddy Lee would have
made ideal girls if they had been playing in
Chicago.
Alan Woods showed that he was a practical
when he kissed Charlotte. Freddy didn't
like it a bit.
Did you ever see Dr. Ogden at a loss for a
word before?
Sergeant Lugg (Jack Fulton) deserves a
beat in Highlandtown.
Dick McCabe, if he tried hard enough,
might make the beauty squad.

THE DANCE.
We do not think that scientific descriptions
of the sun's rays and similar ornaments are
suitable decorations for McCoy Hall on the
night of the dance. We think that the Dance
Committee should be careful in the future to
have them removed and more modern pictures
substituted. We also make the stock suggestion that more chaperons be persuaded to
come. Both of these things could easily be
arranged if the Dance Committee would be
willing to take a little extra trouble.

Billy Haynes looked as young as those in
the graduating class at the Calvert School.
It is difficult to do justice to Teddy Guerad
and Calvin Goddard.
''Ham' Owens improved with time.

COMPETITION IN COLLEGE.
III view of President Hadley's remarkably
able address delivered a few days ago at the
university, may we venture to make a suggestion? Dr. Hadley calls for the element of
competition to appear in the undergraduate
colleges. Surely Princeton has well answered
this question by establishing 'honor groups."
The classes here are not very large, but in
cases where the number is over thirty, ought
not `'honor groups" to be established? Surely
this is a certain way of obtaining competition.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

TRACK NOTES.
Saturday, February 13th, was a day of disappointment for our track team, for adverse
circumstances caused the downfall of both of
our relay teams. Our mile-relay team competed for the indoor collegiate championship
in the Columbia Games, New York, and,
owing to the spill of the ffrst man, Bridgman,
lost their chances to make good. It is said
that the track was in wretched condition at
the curves and this was the reason of 'Bridgman's fall. It is doubtful, however, whether
we could have beaten Harvard, for the time,
3.32 4-5 is better than a Black and Blue university team has ever done. The men ran in
the following order: Bridgeman, Baily (captain), Fulton, Stollenwerck.
Our two mile relay team were entered in
the George Washington Games, in Washington. When they arrived at the Convention
Hall, they were informed that there was no
two mile team to compete with them; so they
were forced to run the crack Cornell mile
relay. One concession was made, however,
and that is that the distance was set at a mile
and a quarter. Of course the Cornell men
ran away from our distance men, so there is
no more to say about it. The team was composed of Breyer, Makel, Burgas' and Griffith.
In the mile handicap event "Dutch" Breyer
made good. He started from scratch, and
overtaking a field of 31, finished third.

INVITATION FROM PENN.
Manager Stewart, of the Track Team, has
received an invitation to name entries for the
15th annual relay races to be held by the
University of Pennsylvania on Saturday,
April 25th.
The invitation, in part, reads as follows:
"There will be three races to determine the
college championship of America, and they
will be open to any college or university that
desires to enter. One race will be for a distance of a mile, each man to run a quartermile. The second race will be a four mile
race, each mass to run a mile. The third race
will be a two mile race, each man to run a
half mile. The University of Pennsylvania
will be found in all three, and it is expected

that Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Cornell,
Columbia, Chicago, Michigan, Wisconsin,
etc., will also enter them."
'There will be in addition a number of other
races between colleges."
"The relay races have now become so well
known that we hope you will snake a special
effort to send A team. Each year all the big
colleges and schools with hardly an exception
are on hand. The championships and special
events are very high class while the group
races are most interesting. Over 200 teams
have been present for several years, making
this the biggest meet of the year. To be
absent from the relay races is to miss an
athletic treat."
"We shall award the following prizes: A
silk banner will be given to the winning team
as a college trophy, and to each member of
the winning team a gold watch. To each of
the members of the team that finishes second
we shall give a silver cup. Cups will be
given as third prizes. If only three colleges
are able to enter the race, we shall give a silk
banner to the winning team, and a gold watch
to each of its members. Second prizes will be
given when four teams contest, third prizes
will be given when six teams contest. In
case your institution should enter and the
other colleges with which we have classed
you should not enter, we shall make arrangements to put you in a race with some other
teams about your equal in strength."
"We expect to give the following scratch
events, open only to college men, graduate or
undergraduate, in which the first prize will be
a gold watch: One hundred yards dash, 120yards hurdle, high jump, broad jump, shot
put, hammer throw, discus and pole vault."
``The races will be governed by the same
rules of qualification that now prevail in the
Intercollegiate Athletic Association."
``No entrance fee will be charged."

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE SOPHOMORE BANQUET.
The Sophomore Banquet was held at the
New St. James Hotel, on Friday, February
18th. It was most successful in every way.
The toastmaster was Harvey Musser, who
was very happy in his remarks. The following toasts were responded to: Harry C. Burgan, president, to our class; W. B. Waters, to
the football team; E. 0. Hulbert, to the
lacrosse team; Ben. Tappan, to the track
team; and Mason Patillo, to "those that have
fallen by the wayside."
The speeches were fine and to the point and
the singing, led by the famous Wilson and
A general
Cooper quartet was excellent.
atmosphere of good nature and "roughhouse" prevailed, and after a rousing cheer
for the class of nineteen eleven the banquet
broke up—no one feeling the worse for the

A Kansas editor is guilty of the following :
A couple were recently married. The ceremony over, the wife began to weep copiously.
"What's the matter ?" asked the new husband. "I never told you that I didn't know
how to cook," sobbed the bride. "Don't
fret," said he, "I'll not have anything to
cook; I'm an editor."

The street car was crowded. The perspiring conductor pushed his way to the platform,
rang up a dozen or so fares, and then gave a
sigh of relief. The worst part of his work
was done.
The car went on to the next transfer station
and then stopped. A fashionably dressed
woman made her way to the door, and,
pausing before she lighted, opened up her
pocketbook, took out a dollar bill, handed it

Chocolates

Bonbons

to the conductor, and sweetly said:
"You forgot to collect my fare, my good
man."
The conductor gave her ninety-five cents
change, touched his hat, and. turning to a
passenger, said:
"Now, that's what I call a perfect lady."
But suddenly the smile froze on his lips,
for, as he looked more closely at the dollar
bill, he saw that it was counterfeit.
